title: How to Choose the Best Plant at the Nursery

steps.headline: Be aware that the biggest plant does not always mean the best.
steps.description: A large plant might suffer more shock being transferred from the pot to the garden than a smaller one. If you are going to grow a large plant, such as a 2-3 year old tree, get good, solid advice from the nursery employees about its chances and your garden situation, as you're going to be paying a good price for this plant and it's important that it take to your garden well.

steps.headline: Look for signs of unhealthiness.
steps.description: When looking at the plants you would like to take home, look for any signs of disease.

steps.headline: Look for blemishes, spots, discoloration and other pest damage on leaves, stems, and branches of the plants.
steps.description: This is likely a sign of pest infestation.

steps.headline: Avoid plants with weeds growing in the pot.
steps.description: This means it has been sitting in the pot too long and its care has been neglected.

steps.headline: Avoid plants whose roots are growing out the base of the pot.
steps.description: Again, the plant's needs have been neglected.

steps.headline: Check to see if the plant has been well tended or neglected.
steps.description: Check soil moisture, pruning, general look etc. Recent pruning might indicate removal of unhealthy growth. Be a careful inspector.

steps.headline: Choose from the best plants left.
steps.description: Once you have discarded some plants for the above reasons, it is a case of which plant looks best in shape and appeals to you most. After a while, you'll get a very quick "feel" for doing this.

If you are going to grow a large plant, such as a 2-3 year old tree, get good, solid advice from the nursery employees about its chances and your garden situation, as you're going to be paying a good price for this plant and it's important that it take to your garden well. Look for signs of unhealthiness. When looking at the plants you would like to take home, look for any signs of disease. Look for blemishes, spots, discoloration and other pest damage on leaves, stems, and branches of the plants. This is likely a sign of pest infestation. Avoid plants with weeds growing in the pot. This means it has been sitting in the pot too long and its care has been neglected. Avoid plants whose roots are growing out the base of the pot. Again, the plant's needs have been neglected. Check to see if the plant has been well tended or neglected. Check soil moisture, pruning, general look etc. Recent pruning might indicate removal of unhealthy growth. Be a careful inspector. Choose from the best plants left. Once you have discarded some plants for the above reasons, it is a case of which plant looks best in shape and appeals to you most. After a while, you'll get a very quick "feel" for doing this.
